title: Your Presentation Title Here
section: Making your Slides FAIR (Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, Reusable)
text:
Making your Slides FAIR (Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, Reusable)
Step 1 create a new repository on your GitHub name this yourGitHubusername.github.io  Step 2 Add a ReadMe file and type Hello World! This will be your home page if you do not already have one. Any time you work on a new repository and publish this it will be a sub-directory of the page.  Step 3 Clone the repository from the following link https://omiridoue.github.io/20240814_PaNs  Step 4 There are many ways to host the presentation you are about to render through Quarto. We will render this locally and tell Quarto to output all files in html format to the docs subfolder. We will then tell GitHub to look for these files and deploy our html slides.

title: Your Presentation Title Here
text:
Continued - Follow Along Today’s Material
Step 5 Create a repository on your GitHub and name this 20240814_PaNs  Step 6 Follow the steps from https://docs.github.com/en/get-started/getting-started-with-git/managing-remote-repositories to sync your local and remote repositories, make sure to push all this content to your remote repository. The aim by the end of this session is to make your slides public and findable under the following URL https://yourGitHubusername.github.io/20240814_PaNs. Note if you have a GitHub Education page you don’t need to make the repository public, but your slides and homepage will be public.

title: Your Presentation Title Here
text:
Continued - Follow Along Today’s Material
Step 7 This is the last part of setting up. We need to navigate to the settings of our new repository and click through these steps.

title: Your Presentation Title Here
text:
Intended Outcomes

Render the template locally

Sync your local to your remote repository
Deploy your slides from your /docs branch

Begin to tinker with the template
Understand the folder structure of the template
Understand what different components within Quarto do
Understand how to modify the settings configured within Quarto

title: Your Presentation Title Here
section: Quarto recognises ## as a command to make a new slide
text:
Quarto recognises ## as a command to make a new slide
Customise these headings by tinkering with the styles.css file. Maybe we can come up with a Quarto template for SPHSU branding? To tinker with the fonts/colors go to the styles.css document and navigate to the different heading definitions.
Heading 3 - three #’s
Heading 4 - four #’s
Heading 5 - five #’s
Heading 6 - six #’s

title: Your Presentation Title Here
text:
Features in your Text
If you want to start a new line of text add a <br> at the end  of a line 
You can make text bold by adding two asterisks on either end of a phrase
Add Text to Your Hyperlink
Anything you wrap inside these back ticks will appear as highlighted text in line for example Ctrl+R.


To draw your attention here I’ve added a >. This page has nothing to do with narwhals but is related to Networks- https://inarwhal.github.io/NetworkAnalysisR-book/

title: Your Presentation Title Here
section: Intermission - What is one unique characteristic of the narwhal that makes it easily distinguishable from other sea creatures?
text:
Intermission - What is one unique characteristic of the narwhal that makes it easily distinguishable from other sea creatures?

Its unusual pink colour
The fringe of “hair”
Its tusk
Its square head

Read in Figures from your /images folder
Once you open your R project you will be able to load images through the relative path images/



Add an image caption here

title: Your Presentation Title Here
text:
What are Code Chunks?
Code chunks will include all your code, you can click Insert a new code chunk to your top right. Each chunk should have its own name. You can add a name after the first reserved word which refers to the language your code is interpreted with, this will be lowercase r for any R code. Follow the chunk name by a comma. To name chunks try avoid using dashes, if there is an error with your code the error message will let you know which chunk you might want to look for to fix this. For R to recognise that you want it to run the code in your chunk, you will need to type eval = TRUE. If you do not want to run this code each time you render the document change to eval = FALSE. If you want to print your code in the slides add echo = TRUE. There are a couple of more options you might want to check like warnings or message to suppress any messages. For the following chunk we specify {r, eval = FALSE, echo=TRUE}.

require(network)

title: Your Presentation Title Here
text:
Easy Navigation
Quickly jump to other parts of your presentation
Toggle the slide menu with the menu button (bottom left of slide) to go to other slides and access presentation tools.
You can also press m to toggle the menu open and closed.

Learn more: Navigation

title: Your Presentation Title Here
text:
Chalkboard
Free form drawing and slide annotations
Use the chalkboard button at the bottom left of the slide to toggle the chalkboard.
Use the notes canvas button at the bottom left of the slide to toggle drawing on top of the current slide.
You can also press b to toggle the chalkboard or c to toggle the notes canvas.

Learn more: Chalkboard

title: Your Presentation Title Here
text:
Literature
Citations
Citations follow the standard Quarto format and be sourced from BibLaTex, BibTeX, or CLS files. You will need to navigate to the bibliography section of your yaml at the top of this document to specify the name of the file that contains all yuor reference information. For example:

Diffusion of Innovations (Rogers 1983; Kermack and McKendrick 1939; Valente 1996)
Teenage Glasgow Friendship Network (Michell and Amos 1997, 1996; Bush and Michell 1997; Michell 1997b, 1997a; Pearson M. and Michell 2000; S. Pearson M. and Snijders 2006; C. Steglich, Snijders, and Pearson 2010; S. Steglich C. and Pearson 2006; Veenstra and Steglich 2012)

title: Your Presentation Title Here
text:
Data

(a) Friendship Network(b) Descriptive Measures


Click anywhere on this pane to wake up the plot.
# Define a server for the Shiny app
function(input, output) {
  
  # Fill in the spot we created for a plot
  output$phonePlot <- renderPlot({
    # Render a barplot
    barplot(WorldPhones[,input$region]*1000, 
            main=input$region,
            ylab="Number of Telephones",
            xlab="Year")
  })
}

Methods






Explain your model


\[
P_{\theta,\mathcal{Y}}(\mathbf{Y=y|X})=\frac{exp\{\theta^{\textsf{T}}g(y,X)\}}{\kappa(\theta,\mathcal{Y})}
\qquad(1)\]



Every time you refer to your equation use the tag (@referencetoequation) to refer to your equation like so (Equation 1).

You can wrap LaTeX code in line, to do this use a single dollar sign on either end of your code for example no self-nominations were allowed in the Teenage Glasgow Friendship Data, this means 0 values along our diagonal \(A_{ii}=0\). You can also dynamically refer to a variable output in line, simply use back-ticks around your in line code in this case R. The reciprocity for wave 3 friendships is 0.64, if we round it. Next we’ll use (Equation 1) to explain present our methods.

title: Your Presentation Title Here
text:
Methods

library(ergm)
friendship_network <- as.network(friendships_t1)

Model_1 <- ergm(friendship_network ~ edges)

Model_01_GOF <- gof(Model_1, 
                    GOF = ~idegree + odegree + espartners + distance, 
                        verbose = TRUE, 
                        control = control.gof.ergm(seed = 12345))


Highlight specific lines for emphasis
Incrementally highlight additional lines

To cross-reference your model fit, you have several options, for example:

This will take you to your Appendix
Quarto’s native cross-reference label would be “See Section 2.9.”


Learn more: Line Highlighting and Cross References

title: Your Presentation Title Here
text:
References


Bush, P. West, H., and L. Michell. 1997. “The Role of Friendship Groups in the Uptake and Maintenance of Smoking Amongst Pre-Adolescent and Adolescent Children: Distribution of Frequencies.” MRC Medical Sociology Unit Glasgow, no. 62.


Kermack, W. O., and A. G. McKendrick. 1939. “Contributions to the Mathematical Theory of Epidemics: V. Analysis of Experimental Epidemics of Mouse-Typhoid; a Bacterial Disease Conferring Incomplete Immunity.” Journal of Hygiene 39 (3): 271–88. https://doi.org/10.1017/S0022172400011918.


Michell, Lynn. 1997a. “Loud, Sad or Bad: Young People’s Perceptions of Peer Groups and Smoking.” Health Education Research 12 (1): 1–14.


———. 1997b. “Pressure Groups: Young People’s Accounts of Peer Pressure to Smoke.” Social Sciences in Health 3: 3–17.


Michell, Lynn, and Amanda Amos. 1996. “Peer Pressure to Smoke: The Meaning Depends on the Method.” Health Education Research 11 (1): 39–49.


———. 1997. “Girls, Pecking Order and Smoking.” Social Science & Medicine 44 (12): 1861–69. https://doi.org/10.1016/S0277-9536(96)00295-X.


Pearson, M., and Lynn Michell. 2000. “Smoke Rings: Social Network Analysis of Friendship Groups, Smoking and Drug-Taking.” Drugs: Education, Prevention and Policy 7: 21–37.


Pearson, Steglich, M., and A. Snijders T. 2006. “Homophily and Assimilation Among Sport-Active Adolescent Substance Users.” Connections 27 (1): 47–63.


Rogers, Everett M. 1983. Diffusion of Innovations. 3. ed. New York, NY: Free Press.


Steglich, Christian, Tom A. B. Snijders, and Michael Pearson. 2010. “Dynamic Networks and Behavior: Separating Selection from Influence.” Sociological Methodology 40 (1): 329–93. https://doi.org/10.1111/j.1467-9531.2010.01225.x.


Steglich, Snijders, C., and M. Pearson. 2006. “Applying SIENA: An Illustrative Analysis of the Co-Evolution of Adolescents’ Friendship Networks, Taste in Music, and Alcohol Consumption.” Connections 2: 48–56.


Valente, Thomas W. 1996. “Social Network Thresholds in the Diffusion of Innovations.” Social Networks 18 (1): 69–89. https://doi.org/10.1016/0378-8733(95)00256-1.


Veenstra, R., and Ch. Steglich. 2012. “Actor-Based Model for Network and Behavior Dynamics.” In Handbook of Developmental Research Methods, edited by B. Laursen, T. D. Little, and N. A. Card, 598–618. Guilford Press.
